The first successful engine produced on this principle was the R.E.P., named after its inventor, Robert Esnault-Pelterie

Although, for special reasons, the inventor of the R.E.P. has* preferred to mount the cylinders on the upper portion of the crankcase only, the method of operation does not differ from those engines having the cylinders placed at equal intervals around the periphery of the crankcase.
